<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 379, 144]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSE™  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 170, 183, 187]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 194, 368, 210]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 170, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/23  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[782, 194, 905, 210]]<|/det|>
May/June 2020  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[814, 217, 905, 231]]<|/det|>
45 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 246, 507, 263]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 277, 435, 293]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[215, 291, 539, 320]]<|/det|>
Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 337, 227, 352]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 353, 112, 368]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[129, 352, 601, 369]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 368, 907, 400]]<|/det|>
For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}\) , \(\mathbf{B}\) , \(\mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\) . Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 400, 578, 415]]<|/det|>
Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 416, 277, 431]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 431, 868, 462]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 462, 327, 476]]<|/det|>
Do not use correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 477, 364, 492]]<|/det|>
Do not write on any bar codes.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 492, 329, 507]]<|/det|>
You may use a calculator.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 507, 672, 523]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 550, 220, 564]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 565, 390, 581]]<|/det|>
The total mark for this paper is 40.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 581, 806, 597]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 597, 571, 613]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 94, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 529, 91]]<|/det|>
Diagram 1 shows a solid, rectangular-sided block.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[351, 100, 645, 212]]<|/det|>

diagram 1

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 257, 662, 276]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 514, 544, 532]]<|/det|>
diagram 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 545, 625, 562]]<|/det|>
Metre rules have been shown close to the edges of the block.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 575, 390, 593]]<|/det|>
What is the volume of the block?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 134, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 602, 222, 620]]<|/det|>
120 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 602, 303, 620]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 602, 390, 620]]<|/det|>
168 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[455, 602, 480, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[485, 602, 556, 621]]<|/det|>
264 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 603, 640, 621]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[650, 603, 734, 621]]<|/det|>
1155 cm³

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 97, 89]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 636, 91]]<|/det|>
A student investigates the motion of a ball rolling down a slope.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 101, 625, 120]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows the speed \(v\) of the ball at different times \(t\).

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[176, 128, 818, 291]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 303, 529, 322]]<|/det|>
Which statement describes the motion of the ball?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 332, 134, 351]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 332, 420, 351]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is not constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 357, 133, 376]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 357, 390, 376]]<|/det|>
The acceleration is negative.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 133, 403]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 384, 361, 403]]<|/det|>
The speed is decreasing.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 410, 133, 428]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 410, 351, 428]]<|/det|>
The velocity is constant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 454, 96, 472]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 454, 504, 472]]<|/det|>
Which statement about acceleration is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 483, 133, 501]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 483, 541, 501]]<|/det|>
It is related to the changing speed of an object.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 509, 133, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 509, 556, 528]]<|/det|>
It is the distance an object travels in one second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 536, 133, 554]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 536, 816, 554]]<|/det|>
It is the force acting on an object divided by the distance it travels in one second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 562, 133, 581]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 562, 650, 581]]<|/det|>
It is the force acting on an object when it is near to the Earth.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 605, 96, 624]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 605, 779, 624]]<|/det|>
Which statement correctly describes the effects of placing a heavy load in a car?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 634, 133, 653]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 634, 695, 653]]<|/det|>
It is easier to accelerate the car and easier to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 660, 133, 679]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 660, 745, 679]]<|/det|>
It is easier to accelerate the car but more difficult to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 687, 133, 705]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 687, 803, 705]]<|/det|>
It is more difficult to accelerate the car and more difficult to bring the car to rest.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 713, 133, 732]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 713, 745, 732]]<|/det|>
It is more difficult to accelerate the car but easier to bring the car to rest.

The diagram shows the mass and the spring at different points during the motion. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[175, 383, 819, 594]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 609, 922, 641]]<|/det|> At which point does the mass have the least gravitational potential energy and at which point is the most elastic energy stored in the spring? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 653, 594, 816]]<|/det|>

500 000 Pa

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 470, 640, 489]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 777, 133, 795]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 777, 574, 795]]<|/det|>
A heavy atomic nucleus splits and absorbs energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 72, 104, 88]]<|/det|>
<label>38</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 72, 510, 89]]<|/det|>
A radioactive material has a half-life of 20 days.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 102, 541, 120]]<|/det|>
A sample of the material contains \(8.0 \times 10^{10}\) atoms.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 133, 564, 151]]<|/det|>
How many atomic nuclei have decayed after 60 days?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 161, 134, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 161, 240, 179]]<|/det|>
\(1.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 161, 303, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[313, 161, 403, 179]]<|/det|>
\(4.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 161, 467, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 161, 570, 179]]<|/det|>
\(6.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 161, 636, 179]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 161, 740, 179]]<|/det|>
\(7.0 \times 10^{10}\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 207, 106, 225]]<|/det|>
<label>39</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 207, 920, 240]]<|/det|>
A thin sheet of paper is placed between a radioactive source and a radiation detector. The count rate falls to a very low reading.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[316, 250, 680, 369]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 384, 633, 402]]<|/det|>
From this result, which type of radiation is the source emitting?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 414, 134, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 414, 243, 432]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 443, 134, 460]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 443, 241, 460]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) -particles

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 470, 133, 488]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 470, 205, 488]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 495, 133, 512]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 495, 210, 512]]<|/det|>
X-rays

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 540, 102, 558]]<|/det|>
<label>40</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 540, 813, 558]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays are emitted by radioactive nuclei when they decay.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 570, 564, 588]]<|/det|>
Which emissions can be deflected by an electric field?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 600, 131, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 600, 411, 618]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles and \(\beta\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 628, 131, 645]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 628, 371, 645]]<|/det|>
\(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 655, 131, 673]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 655, 371, 673]]<|/det|>
\(\gamma\) -rays and \(\alpha\) -particles only

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 682, 133, 700]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 682, 428, 700]]<|/det|>
\(\alpha\) -particles, \(\beta\) -particles and \(\gamma\) -rays
